occurrences.line_text: As weather-beaten ship arriu'd on happie shore.
And said, Faire sonne, God giue you happie chance,
That home ye may report thrise happie newes;
Thrise happie man, who fares them both atweene:
Emongst thine equall peres, where happie blis
Vnto her happie mansion attaine:
The ioyes whereof, and happie fruitfulnesse,
From drowning. But more happie he, then wise
An happie man in his first dayes he was,
And happie father of faire progeny:
Next him king Leyr in happie peace long raind,
And all his labour brought to happie end,
Nothing on earth mote alwaies happie beene.
Happie this Realme, had it remained euer since.
Whether more happie were, to win so goodly pray.
Should happie be, and haue immortall blis:
Extremely ioyed in so happie sight,
And next to none, after that happie day,
May meet againe, and each take happie chance.
Made him seeme happie for so glorious theft;
Lo sluggish Knight the victors happie pray:
To him was fallen for his happie lot,
This happie day I haue to greete you well,
Long may you liue in health and happie state.
Then pardon, O most sacred happie spirit,
Most confidence and hope of happie speed,
Borne of one mother in one happie mold,
Borne at one burden in one happie morne;
Thrise happie mother, and thrise happie morne,
Thrise happie mother, and thrise happie morne,
And he that happie seemes and least in payne,
More happie creatures, then they seem'd to bee,
The which Rinaldo drunck in happie howre,
With whom he ledd a long and happie life;
Thrise happie Ladie, and thrise happie knight,
Thrise happie Ladie, and thrise happie knight,
So nought may be esteemed happie till the end.
An happie life with grace and good accord,
That if the happie soules, which doe possesse
Nor happie howre, beheld with gazefull eye,
But what on earth can alwayes happie stand?
Spighting my happie freedome, haue agreed,
With which high God had blest her happie land,
More happie mother would her surely weene,
But to these happie fortunes, cruell Fate
To happie blisse he was full high vprear'd,
Their happie flockes, nor daunger to them draw:
Gan highly to commend the happie life,
How much (sayd he) more happie is the state,
If happie, then it is in this intent,
That maketh wretch or happie, rich or poore:
At length espyes at hand the happie cost,
That O my parents might I happily
Of other worldes he happily should heare?
And sure had it not happily found rest
Betwixt him and his hurt bene happily,
When Artegall arriuing happily,
He chaunst to come, where happily he spide
In which she wont to harbour happily:
Least ye therefore mote happily me blame,
That had to any happily betid,
And now haue prou'd, what happineesse ye hold
Wherein eternall peace and happinesse doth dwell.
Affiance made, my happinesse begonne,
Another happinesse, another end.
Yet no where can her find: such happinesse
And none does others happinesse enuye:
Desired rest, and men of happinesse depriue.
Such happinesse did, maulgre, to me spight,
From courtly blisse and wonted happinesse,
And to her selfe oft wisht like happinesse,
But such as drinck, eternall happinesse do fynd.
I neuer ioyed happinesse nor rest,
They soone would loath their lesser happinesse,
And gan their endlesse happinesse enuye,
For strength, and wealth, and happinesse she lends,
And at her happinesse do fret and frowne:
And flourish in all wealth and happinesse,
That certes I your happinesse enuie,
That here on earth is no sure happinesse,
Thenceforth they ioy'd in happinesse together,
And said, Faire knight, borne vnder happy starre,
O who is that, which brings me happy choyce
O happy Queene of Faeries, that hast found
Thrise happy man, said then the father graue,
Thrise happy man the knight himselfe did hold,
Where is that happy land of Faery,
So happy peace they made and faire accord:
Happy, who can abstaine, when Rancour rife
Like Angels life was then mens happy cace;
Such grace now to be happy, is before thee laid.
Ne to be made so happy do intend:
Thrise happy man, (said then the Briton knight)
O ioyous memorie of happy time,
Nath'lesse the same enioyed but short happy howre:
All happy peace and goodly gouernment
Yet shall he long time warre with happy speed,
But now in stedfast loue and happy state
Of wicked Sprights did fall from happy blis;
O spare thy happy dayes, and them apply
That ioyd in happy peace, till fates peruerse
Whilest thus I spake, behold with happy eye
So euer loose, so euer happy be.
But where so loose or happy that thou art,
Mongst many which maligne her happy state,
Now happy man (sayd then Sir Calidore)
Who from the high degree of happy state,
The happy peace, which there doth ouerflow,
Right happy thou, that mayst them freely see:
Not I so happy, answerd then that swaine,
The hard aduentures and strange haps to tell;
As when the flashing Leuin haps to light
What haps to day to me, to morrow may to you.
Oftimes it haps, that sorrowes of the mynd
And if she hapt of any good to heare,
And wretched sorrowes, which haue often hapt?
Faire harbour that them seemes; so in they entred arre.
He seemd in hart to harbour thoughts vnkind,
Then that I feele, and harbour in mine hart:
But such, as want of harbour did constraine:
Did closely harbour such a iealous guest)
In which she wont to harbour happily:
And harbour here in safety from those rauenous dogs.
Some place shall vs receiue, and harbour yield;
For his sicke charge some harbour there to seeke;
Now farre from harbour likely to be lost,
Finde harbour fit to comfort her great neede.
The noble hart, that harbours vertuous thought,
Downe in a dale, hard by a forests side,
Shooke him so hard, that forced him to speake.
You, whom my hard auenging destinie
On silly Dame, subiect to hard mischaunce,
So hard the discord was to be agreede.
Of her sad troubles and misfortunes hard:
What doe I see? what hard mishap is this,
But few returned, hauing scaped hard,
For greater conquest of hard loue he gaynes,
(A lesson hard) and make the Libbard sterne
That famous hard atchieuements still pursew,
And by hard meanes enforcing her to stay,
Full hard it is (quoth he) to read aright
Through long enprisonment, and hard constraint,
Wherein darke things were writ, hard to be vnderstood.
Or anguish in her hart, is hard to tell:
Vnhappie falles that hard necessitie,
Out of my way, through perils straunge and hard;
Of late most hard atchieu'ment by you donne,
Through many hard assayes, which did betide;
Him fortuned (hard fortune ye may ghesse)
Hard helpe at need. So deare thee babe I bought,
Ye bene right hard amated, gratious Lord,
That hath his sword through hard assay forgone,
And oft approu'd in many hard assay,
What hard mishap him brought to such distresse,
Perdy (said he) here comes, and is hard by
Hard is his hap, that first fals in his ieopardie.
Those that were low themselues, held others hard,
Hath bene thy faithfull aide in hard assay,
And cleauing the hard steele, did deepe inuade
With hard aduenture, which I haue in hand,
His larumbell might lowd and wide be hard,
Him selfe addrest to that aduenture hard:
And many bold repulse, and many hard
Flying from Iunoes wrath and hard assay,
Scarse had he said, when hard at hand they spy
Both firmely armd for euery hard assay,
Right hard it was, for wight, which did it heare,
So hard a workmanship aduenture darre,
That her for witnesse of his hard assay,
And many hard aduentures did atchieue;
For thy hard fortune then thou wouldst renew,
On equall plaine, and there so hard beset;
Seeking aduentures hard, to exercise
Perdie (said Britomart) the choise is hard:
To hunt out perils and aduentures hard,
That man to hard conditions to bind,
But he it knew at home before he hard
Other then my hard fortune to deplore,
Should of his dearest daughters hard misfortune heare.
The hard begin, that meets thee in the dore,
How to effect so hard an enterprize,
And large of limbe, t'atchieue an hard emprize,
Some hard mishap, in hazard of his life:
A lesson too too hard for liuing clay,
That the hard rocks could scarse from teares refraine,
The cold earth was his couch, the hard steele his pillow.
Of his hard hap did vexe his noble brest,
Ne ceased not, till him oppressed hard
Ne euer pittie may relent his malice hard.
Were hard behind, her readie to arrest:
Need teacheth her this lesson hard and rare,
Sith brought she was now to so hard constraint,
Her hard pursewd, and sought for to suppresse;
Which on his helmet martelled so hard,
Into his powre, that vsed her so hard,
What hard misfortune brought me to the same;
Hard is to teach an old horse amble trew.
And to be free from hard restraint and gealous feares.
That weenes with watch and hard restraint to stay
Did all the way him follow hard behind,
When for to compasse Philliras hard loue,
His feeble steps, which shrunke, when hard theron he lay.
Of persons flockt, whose names is hard to read:
She cast to vse, both fit for hard emprize;
That seem'd full hard t'accord two things so far in dout.
And hard aduentures twixt themselues alone,
Hard by the gates of hell her dwelling is,
That whether were more false, full hard it is to tell.
When they the reason of his words had hard,
That hard it was to weene which harder were.
In quyent disguise, full hard to be descride.
So hard, this Idole was to be ared,
The hard aduentures and strange haps to tell;
Vpon an hard aduenture yet in quest,
Or hard misfortune she was thence conuayd,
Yet had it bene right hard him to withstand,
His hard mishap in dolor to deplore,
Ah wofull man, what heauens hard disgrace,
Against all hard mishaps and fortunelesse misfare.
And hard to finde, that heat of youthfull spright
More hard for hungry steed t'abstaine from pleasant lare.
And all the way from trotting hard to spare,
Loe hard behind his backe his foe was prest,
And heauie sway, that hard vnto his crowne
An hard mishap and disauentrous case
Hard is the doubt, and difficult to deeme,
Of two full hard to read the harder theft.
But Britomart did him importune hard,
My hard mishaps, that ye may learne to shonne;
So on that hard aduenture forth I went,
And faint-heart-fooles, whom shew of perill hard
Againe some other, that in hard assaies
Much dearer be the things, which come through hard distresse.
Was hard to know, for that her Priests the same
And valiant hearts, in thoughts lesse hard and bold,
Or ought more hard, then thinke to reckon right.
But his hard rocky hart for no entreating
To come of him, for vsing her so hard,
An hard aduenture, which did then befall,
For there no substance was so firme and hard,
And wend with him on his aduenture hard.
A noble Knight, and tride in hard assayes:
With both his hands behinde him pinnoed hard,
Is falne on you, by heauens hard direction,
Through hard aduentures deedes of armes to try,
No hand so cruell, nor no hart so hard,
So hard it is to be a womans slaue.
Bound vnto me, but not with such hard bands
Let him lodge hard, and lie in strawen bed,
Sometime she feared, least some hard mishap
My Lord, your Loue, by hard mishap doth lie
All which when she with hard enduraunce had
And bake their sides vppon the cold hard stone,
Who whilest in hand it gryping hard he hent,
Which on both sides was then debating hard:
And rare in-sight, hard matters to reuele;
And there her selfe did hyde from his hard tyranny.
Imposd on it, with many a hard condition,
The whiles the Prince hard preased in betweene,
Hard is the case, the which ye doe complaine;
Yet not so hard (for nought so hard may light,
Yet not so hard (for nought so hard may light,
Vppon an hard aduenture sore bestad,
Atchieu'd so hard a quest, as few before;
Vnhappy Squire, what hard mishap thee brought
Hard by a streight there stands a castle strong,
He greater grew, and gan to driue at him more hard.
About him flockt, and hard at him did lay;
Full on the breast him strooke, so strong and hard,
And held the same so hard, that by no wize
An hard aduenture with vnhappie end;
How euer by hard hap he hether came;
Now beating his hard head vpon a stone,
Bout which whilest he was busied thus hard,
Full like ere long to haue escaped hard;
And gainst the cold hard earth so sore him strake,
So hard a taske, as life for hyre to sell;
Through such her stubborne stifnesse, and hard hart,
Or else abide the death, that hard before you stands.
For penaunce of my proud and hard rebellious hart.
And night arriued hard at hand, began
To merchants, which them kept in bondage hard,
Putting his puissaunce forth, pursu'd so hard,
In which his harder fortune was to fall
His harder hide would neither perce, nor bight,
Nor harder was from Cerberus greedie iaw
A harder lesson, to learne Continence
With harder meanes he cast her to subdew,
For discord harder is to end then to begin.
(The harder it to make them well agree)
That hard it was to weene which harder were.
Of two full hard to read the harder theft.
That harder may be ended, then begonne.
That hardest heart would bleede, to heare their piteous mone.
Each goodly thing is hardest to begin,
That sure I weene, the hardest hart of stone,
Doe pearce the rockes, and hardest marble weares;
Are now transformed into hardest stone:
With hardie fowle, aboue his hable might,
Since he this hardie enterprize began:
But he was not so hardie to abide
Vntill the hardie Mayd (with loue to frend)
And of the hardie Britomarts successe:
These three that hardie chalenge tooke in hand,
For noble courage, and for hardie race,
An hardie courage, like captiued thrall,
That who so hardie hand on her doth lay,
Yet nought they feard, but past on hardily,
But full of fire and greedy hardiment,
Of looser life, and heat of hardiment,
For mine offence and heedlesse hardiment,
Hardly could he endure his hardiment,
To make more triall of his hardiment,
With stedfast courage and stout hardiment;
By your good counsell, or bold hardiment,
Yet had he not the hart, nor hardiment,
And in his port appeared manly hardiment.
Of straunge affaires, and noble hardiment,
And courage full of haughtie hardiment,
Met him mid-way with equall hardiment,
Whom he assayld with dreadlesse hardiment,
But thankt be God, and your good hardiment,
That both thy loue, for lacke of hardiment,
Least his too haughtie hardines might reare
From a bold knight, that with great hardinesse
Who through great prowesse and bold hardinesse,
But hardly was restreined of that aged sire.
Which hardly doen, at length she gan them pray,
She hardly yet perswaded was to stay,
So hardly he the flitted life does win,
Whom hardly he from flying forward stayd,
Could hardly him intreat, to tell his griefe:
For hardly could be hurt, who was already stong.
The fish that once was caught, new bait will hardly bite.
Hardly could he endure his hardiment,
That armd with fire, more hardly he mote him withsto[n]d.
With some late perill, which he hardly past,
Who all this while full hardly was assayd
Would hardly find to aggrauate her griefe;
Escaped hardly, hardly praisd his wedlock good.
Escaped hardly, hardly praisd his wedlock good.
That hardly he with life away does fly,
Nathlesse he hardly of her chearefull speech
For hardly could he come the carle to touch,
Where hardly eye mote see bright heauens face,
By which I hardly past with much adoe:
So hardly butted those two twinnes of Ioue,
Can hardly but by Sacrament be tride,
That yron heart it hardly could sustaine:
That hardly passable on foote it was:
Albe the wyld-man hardly would refraine.
So doubtfully, that hardly one could know
And eke but hardly seene by candle-light:
Him hardly forward drew, whereas the thiefe
Vpon his crest the hardned yron fell,
But his more hardned crest was armd so well,
Were hardned with that holy water dew,
Is hardned more with my aboundant teares.
Their hardned hearts, enur'd to bloud and cruelty.
Enur'd to hardnesse and to homely fare,
My former hardnesse first I faire excusd;
Let him feele hardnesse of thy heauie arme:
But cruelty and hardnesse from you chace,
The one vpon his hardy head him plast,
And him in hardy battaile ouercame,
And dayly how through hardy enterprize,
Was hight Sir Huddibras, an hardy man;
For his bold feats and hardy confidence,
In great disdaine, he answerd; Hardy Elfe,
Well hoped he, ere long that hardy guest,
Of hardy Nennius, whom he yet did slay,
Dare not for dread his hardy hand expose,
For hardy thing it is, to weene by might,
And passing Dee with hardy enterprise,
That stroke the hardy Squire did sore displease,
He from such hardy boldnesse was restraind,
Yet her the hardy knight pursewd so nye,
And with the first the hardy Satyrane
An hardy hart, and his wide mouth did gape
Whereto she euer list to make her hardy flight.
The hardy boy, as they deuised had,
Enflam'd with fury and fiers hardy-hed,
To wrecke on them their follies hardyment:
Who from them fled, as light-foot hare from vew
To which all harkning, did a while asswage
Saying, that harlot she too lately knew,
Thy maisters shame, in harlots bondage tide.
That nought mote perce, ne might his corse be harmd
That erst him goodly arm'd, now most of all him harm'd.
Where soone he slumbred, fearing not be harm'd,
Of euery place, that was with brusing harmd,
A downe in vaine, ne harm'd her any more.
But when he heard of harme, he wexed wondrous glad.
Late learnd what harme to hastie trust ensu'th,
For till that stownd could neuer wight him harme,
For feare of further harme, I counsell thee,
But whence should come that harme, which thou doest seeme
Though otherwise it did him litle harme:
For neither can he fly, nor other harme,
That could doe harme, yet could not harmed bee,
For she of womans force did feare no harme;
Both in remembrance of his friends late harme,
Whereto thus Scudamour, Small harme it were
Ouer his head, before the harme came neare.
For feare of harme, that might lie hidden there;
Who will not stoupe with good, shall be made stoupe with harme.
Or harme, that any had, then would she make
Harme may arise vnweeting vnto me;
That could doe harme, yet could not harmed bee,
Some fearing shriekt, some being harmed hould,
And th'other two well likely to haue harmed.
Which in false griefe hyding his harmefull guile,
Whose harmefull head, thrice heated in the fire,
The heate whereof, and harmefull pestilence
His harmefull club he gan to hurtle hye,
Then hurling vp his harmefull blade on hye,
Of harmefull fowles about them fluttering, cride,
And eke the biting of that harmefull Beast
Tho gan to him discouer all his harmes,
He hearkned, and did stay from further harmes,
Such helplesse harmes yts better hidden keepe,
By triall of his former harmes and cares,
And naked brest, in pitty of their harmes,
And dolefull sorrow heape with deadly harmes:
His chiefest lets and authors of his harmes,
There whereas all the plagues and harmes abound,
But gazed on their harmes, not pittying their estate.
That by their many wounds, and carelesse harmes,
But on their common harmes together did deuise.
Them thether brought, and how their harmes befell.
Is he, that doth to trauellers such harmes?
And broke his sword, for feare of further harmes,
Ne ought was feared of his certaine harmes:
Was there consorted in one harmonee,
Chaunted alowd their chearefull harmonie:
Ioying to heare the birdes sweete harmony,
His treble, a straunge kinde of harmony;
Her looser notes with Lydian harmony;
The whiles a most delitious harmony,
A goodly knight, all armd in harnesse meete,
Another harnesse, which did hang thereby,
Eftsoones the people all to harnesse ran,
As when Ioues harnesse-bearing Bird from hie
Alreadie harnessed for iourney new;
Yet harnessed his firie-footed teeme,
His siluer Harpe in hand, and shortly friends them make.
Who playing on his harpe, vnto him drew
The hellish Harpies, prophets of sad destiny.
Harrow now out, and well away, he cryde,
Harrow, the flames, which me consume (said hee)
Against that knight: Harrow and well away,
And he that harrowd hell with heauie stowre,
That glorious fire it kindled in his hart,
And euer as he rode, his hart did earne
That nigh his manly hart did melt away,
Her chast hart had subdewd, to learne Dame pleasures toy.
Her swollen hart her speach seemd to bereaue,
For all so deare as life is to my hart,
And said, Faire Lady hart of flint would rew
Her hart gan melt in great compassion,
How does he find in cruell hart to hate
At last in close hart shutting vp her paine,
His bleeding hart is in the vengers hand,
That should as death vnto my deare hart light:
Cruell reuenge, which he in hart did hyde,
And launcht his Lordly hart: with death opprest
That stony hart could riuen haue in twaine,
And rash misweening doe thy hart remoue:
And in his hand a burning hart he bare,
He seemd in hart to harbour thoughts vnkind,
And bad say on the secret of her hart.
But in eternall woes my weaker hart
The noble hart, that harbours vertuous thought,
In hart, and chaunge in that great mothers face:
Yet pittie in her hart was neuer proued
Her constant hart did tempt with diuerse guile:
And burnt his beastly hart t'efforce her chastitye.
Such fearefull fit assaid her trembling hart,
That cruell word her tender hart so thrild,
Yet might her pitteous hart be seene to pant and quake.
Would faine haue dyde: dead was his hart within,
At last recouering hart, he does begin
Perce to my hart, and pas through euery side,
Then that I feele, and harbour in mine hart:
And almost rent her tender hart in tway;
For to vnfold the anguish of your hart:
For wondrous anguish in his hart it wrought,
Such percing griefe her stubborne hart did wound,
Of pitty deare his hart was thrilled sore,
Could make a stony hart his hap to rew;
Could euer find, to grieue the gentlest hart on ground?
And slombring soft my hart did steale away,
Was neuer hart so rauisht with delight,
Could his bloud-frosen hart emboldned bee,
Into the hart, and searcheth euery vaine,
Paine, hunger, cold, that makes the hart to quake;
That as a swords point through his hart did perse,
To come, and goe with tydings from the hart,
Ne let vaine words bewitch thy manly hart,
Her hart with ioy vnwonted inly sweld,
